data.text: SPD Style versus Regular Shoes for Cycle Touring?
On tour do you prefer bike shoes SPD Style or regular shoes and non clamping pedals
Regular shoes and flat pedals , as I like to hike , and I don't want to sound like a tap dancer when walking into a shop/restaurant etc
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: SPDs (Mountain bike cleats) are recessed so they don’t touch the floor. Probably not great for hiking though.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text:
I wore SPDs for a long time. While they may not touch the floor, they are not really comfortable to walk around in for an hour. Alee Dunham (cyclingaround.com) did a study on the efficiency gained with spds over flats. Turns out , unless you are really going fast, there isn't much difference.
HugeDomains.com
hugedomains.com
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: John Goldman , people who say 'spd' are more 'efficient' clearing don't understand the meaning of 'efficiency' , although I fully accept there may be other reasons for using them. Ps, the title of this facebook group is 'bicycle touring for beginners' not how to win a cycle race.
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: I am more comfortable being clipped in. Otherwise, my feet sometimes slip on the pedal which sometimes proves to be painful. I have another bike I use in the winter with just regular shoes and the spds just feel like I have more control. That being said, after 50 or so miles on a fully loaded bike I switch to the flat side for a bit to alleviate some of the discomfort from the cleats. Then I clip back in. GCN I believe also did a study on the efficiency question and came to the same conclusion but I came back to personal preference with perhaps a little “don’t confuse me with the facts?” I’m not a racer and sure don’t go fast! Rad has a very good video on footwear selection. They prefer sandals. Looked at the options long and hard and wound up back where I started!
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: BTW I’m not seeing many “beginner” postings which is okay except that the name of the group is a misnomer based on postings.
data.author: Tess Bois

data.text: We have to have the more experienced here to help the inexperienced.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Combo pedals & SPD sandals, so I can go either way, which I do.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: I have SPD and SPD-R pedals on my racing bikes. For touring I much prefer old-style chromed toe clips with leather QR straps - curiously, the same type I started using for all types of riding over 50 years ago. For touring I rarely cinch them up very tight, even for hard effort hill climbing.
data.author: Stuart Agutter

data.text: SPD clipped in all the way.
data.author: Daniel Trump

data.text: SPD pedals,gives you more control whilst cycling.
data.author: Ray Loughran

data.text: SPD for me
data.author: Stephen Kingdom

data.text: SPD shoes and pedals that have one side flat. That way I get the best of both worlds. I use the bike shoes as my regular shoes on tour because they are comfortable to walk in also.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: me, too.
data.author: Phidias Chinaglia

data.text: I use cycle shoes and toe clips ,fell off a few too many times using spd peddles
data.author: Clive Beach

data.text: I use these Shimano pedals with mountain bike shoes that I can walk in , these pedals are also flat on the other side so it’s the best of both worlds
data.author: Joe Marganski

data.text: I agree. I rode these type of pedals from Seattle to Boston with the best success imaginable. The shoes were well suited to walking, hiking and riding. I had one pair of Sandals(with cleats) and one pair of light MTB shoes (also with cleats). There is the often unmentioned ability to push and pull with cleats. Important if the is much climbing
data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: I have Touring shoes (it's a thing ) & my old steel quill Campagnolo pedals with toe clips & straps ... but I'm Old ...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: With toeclip pedals the shoe fit can be comfy & loose, with clipless pedals the shoe fit has to be tighter ..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Mini toe clips and smaller tennis shoes

data.text: Toe clips ftw
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I use shimano mtn bike shoes with recessed spd cleats and a shimano pedal that is flat on one side.

data.text:
I used trail-runner shoes and Power Straps. Allowed more efficacy than standard pedals and kept me from having other shoes. data.text: Spd it's like seatbelts in a car once you have the habit you feel naked without 😆

data.text: Flat pedals and sandals.
data.author: Brandon Wasser

data.text: I ride with crocs and flats here in the tropics.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: I did a 1500 mile tour in West USA and I started with SPD's but I changed to flats 1/2 way thru and just rode in my bedrock sandals because it was just way more comfortable.
data.author: Brandon Wasser

data.text: Now that i've got used to SPD's, it took time, i wouldn't go back ... they hold your feet in place where they should be
data.author: Danny Simmons

data.text: Regular comfy shoes (I wear skateboard shoes a lot) and platform pedals with wide fabric straps. I’ve used metal cages in the past, and those are fine too, but they rust. I use clipless pedals and road cycling shoes on my trainer, but otherwise I prefer more multi-purpose shoes.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: Good question. No wrong answers. Each to their own.
data.author: Adrian Martyn-Fisher

data.text: Normal shoes. You can get double sided pedals. You can then have a pair of sandals and if necessary a light weight pair of trainers.
data.author: John Mellor

data.text: SPD sandals. They are a thing.
data.author: Aaron Rud

data.text: I have Shimano spd sandals

data.text: Best of both worlds - I have dual sided spd / flat pedals, and my old Keen Commuter sandals that I can wear as SPD or as regular sandals
data.author: Andrea Rose

data.text: I actually prefer SPD SL road cycling cleats. I carry a light weight pair of regular shoes with me.
data.author: D Gerit Slikkers

data.text: I use these, best of 3 worlds. Flats for more knarly gravel, clips for the road and no walking noise on the pub floor 🤘 Check out my latest upload if you're interested 👌 https://youtu.be/p3LwH8e6d9E
data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.text: Keen hiking sandals and metal toothed pedals. Shoes go from water to woods to the bike and don't slip. Easy to rinse on muddy trails.

data.text: I wear the exact same sandals and pedals! I’m a laid back rider and 71

data.text: Except they don’t make them anymore.

data.text: the Keens?

data.text: For me, no shoes is the only way to ride a bike....

data.text: Flat bottom, no clip MTB shoes [Specialized 2FO ROOST FLAT]... IMHO the stiffness transfers more power than regular sneakers or athletic shoes plus they are easy to walk around in. All this with platform pedals

data.text: SPD 100%
data.author: Kristina Kalaj

data.text: Shimano Duel sided SPD. Either bike shoes or my Keen sandels. Very nice when its raining
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: If I’m racing I use clipped pedals. If I’m not I don’t. Spoiler alert; I don’t race.
data.author: Craig Turner

data.text: Double sided clip in SPD style mountain bike style cleats, recessed. I find I can use these for everything, including side hikes. I don't carry any other footwear when touring. (I use Time ATAC's rather than Shimano SPD brand, but concept is the same.)
data.author: Ian Houghton

data.text: Flats with plastic toe clips and a good stiff running or hiking shoe
data.author: Jeff Flint

data.text: Flat pedals, MTB shoes. They're good and sticky to give me extra power, look normal (they're canvas) so I don't have to take a second pair of shoes, and I feel safer on rough ground (I tend to ride forest and gravel wherever possible) and in traffic, not having to unclip
data.author: Victoria James

data.text: I use shimano eh500 pedals which are flat on one side and and clips on the other it’s great to be able to switch between the 2 especially in some rough terrain. I wear the shimano ct5 shoes with them as they are a casual shoe with a recessed cleat.
data.author: Jake Belcher

data.text: exactly what I have on my touring and mountain bikes. And I use the sane shoes too. The recessed cleat is a godsend when having to get off and go for a break 🤣
data.author: Carl Land

data.text: Super huge flats for touring. Plenty of foot to pedal surface area for all day riding comfort.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: ooh, I use flats but never thought of looking for super huge ones.! Care to throw any examples in here? 😉
data.author: Si Bush

data.text: SPD recessed clips, bike packed 3000km @ 100km a day enables you to push and pull especially going up steep tracks. Looking at a wider peddle eg Crank Brothers.
data.author: Tim Norton

data.text: I ride BMX, Mountain bike, touring bike and a Klunker bike.. One pair of shoes for all.. Flat pedals for me 👍👍
data.author: Bradly Chipman

data.text: My vote is for mountain bike shoes. Spd clips and you can walk in them.
data.author: Kent Clow

data.text: I'm pretty flexible. If it's going to be an extended trip and I want to simplify, I have some old school clips and straps on my Bianchi. My LHT, on the other hand, has SPDs.
data.author: Jak Conrad

data.text: bicycle traps and hiking shoes https://ae01.alicdn.com/kf/HTB11CzoPXXXXXbqXFXXq6xXFXXXy/Harnais-de-chaussures-de-v-lo-1-paire-bande-de-filature-accessoires-pi-ces-d-entra.jpg_Q90.jpg_.webp
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: If you cycle in sub zero temperatures, SPDs are not your friends. The metal sends a bolt of cold to your toes like a rusty nail. Agony
data.author: Joseph Attlee

data.text: I have recessed clip on so I can walk in them
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: Getting shoe stiffness right is a factor for touring when using SPD. Too flexible and you can get a hot spot from local pedal pressure (hot foot) on a long riding day, as the pressure bearing area on SPD is relatively small. If too stiff its general utility for hiking off the bike drops. I've found my Shimano XC-7's (stiffness 9 on the Shimano scale) a bit too stiff for general touring use. Many will be happy with stiffness 4, though I can get hot foot with that on long days. My personal preference for touring is stiffness ~6 - avoids hot foot, enough flex for hiking.
data.author: Ian Houghton

I had one pair of Sandals(with cleats) and one pair of light MTB shoes (also with cleats). There is the often unmentioned ability to push and pull with cleats. Important if the is much climbing

I had one pair of Sandals(with cleats) and one pair of light MTB shoes (also with cleats). There is the often unmentioned ability to push and pull with cleats. Important if there is much climbing.

I had one pair of Sandals(with cleats) and one pair of light MTB shoes (also with cleats). There is the often unmentioned ability to push and pull with cleats. Important if there is much climbing.

data.text: I dont bother with my spds. Just means I have to carry another pair of shoes as I hav8yet found a pair of spds that are good off the bike. Pedalling performance isnt high on my priority on tour!! I just tootle along on a pair of trail shoes!

data.text: Spd
data.author: Patricia Seifert

data.text: Regular shoes with grippy mountain bike pedals - such a joy after years of believing toe clips/straps and spd were important. I can choose between boots, trainers or sandals - even crocks sometimes - heavenly!
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: The latter. No extra shoes and the ability to walk if needed.
data.author: Anthony Thomas

data.text: Flats and comfy keen sandals or hiking shoes.
data.author: Julia Poelstra

data.text: I ride combo pedals, for flat terrain and climbs I use the SPDs and for descents (especially loose surfaces) I flip them to flats. Why decide when you can have both...
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: barefoot
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: Clamping pedals... :)
data.author: Peter Harger

data.text: I think it partly depends on much distance and time one plans to cycle each day. Cycling in sneakers or casual shoes for long hours often leads to numbness and discomfort in the feet. The stiff soles of cycling shoes reduces much of those symptoms. I use mountain biking shoes with SPD: no issues walking around with them when I'm off the bike.
data.author: David Law

data.text: I use mtb shoes and spd touring pedals ! My wife uses mtb she’s and magpeds and loves them!
data.author: Jim M. Leone

data.text: Toeclip & strap pedals allow loose fitting shoes with a supportive insole... happy feet.. spud shoes have to fit tighter ...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: not a beginner
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I use SPDs with Giro touring/MTB shoes. I can easily and comfortably walk in them.
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: Regular shoes and the biggest flats I can find. Just bought another set of Shimano PD-M8140 Deore XT Flat Pedals/large. Add a set of pedal extenders and it feels like I'm standing on the ground. I can really generate power easily.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: I used to use SPD. Then I learned how to control bike with regular pedals while I was riding freeride and downhill. Now I use regular. Well it is actually platform, so they are bigger (wider) then regular and I love it 😎
data.author: Bojan Petrovic
